Chris Cassidy is currently ALONE on the US section of the International Space Station. How crazy is that? I really enjoyed speaking with him and Jonny. I started this process thinking the Seals probably focus on the ability to overpower the enemy and smash things, but it turns out humility and the ability to work on a team is by far the most important attribute. You can follow Chris and Jonny on twitter and Instagram (I'll put the links in the description).

Thank you to those who are supporting Smarter Every Day on Patreon! ( https://www.patreon.com/smartereveryday ) Did you get your baseballs?

Straight talk: I don't think you need to warn us that nobody put you up to say something or other.

I can think of three categories of audience member you have: 1. a critical thinker will already be seeing red flags all over the place when you are given access to facilities that a regular civilian isn't given access to. The critical thinker will say: even if SED doesn't explicitly agree to anything, there is evidently a benefit in SED showcasing whatever it is he is allowed to showcase. 2. a non-critical thinker will not really be concerned about this anyways, and 3. the "hyper-critical" thinker (i.e. the "nothing ever happens for real" crowd) will only use it as a trigger to be reactionary about it.

All that not-withstanding, nothing you said was really a claim so much as a reporting of fact or an expression of appreciation towards a set of virtues. The SEAL ethos is the SEAL ethos. It has merit simply for being something they're proud of. In a way, it's a self proving document. It would be something else if there were claims like "the world's only" or "the best" etc.

I was watching Away, and I noticed that Popov has his name in Cyrillic, but none of the other astronauts did. In reality, humans have been putting every relevant version of a person’s name on their space suit identifiers to increase the speed of a person recognizing who they are dealing with, and not require people to read in an alphabet other than their own. In fact, the idea that Popov would be the only person with his name in Cyrillic on the suit is pretty weird, because he’s the one for whom Cyrillic is the native script.

My comment is in two parts:
1. To me, it’s completely mind blowing what can be accomplished when we as humans (with an attitude that’s an alloy of humility and ‘can-do’) cooperate. In this video, it’s illustrated obviously by the storied accomplishments of the people of the ISS program, and alluded to more vaguely by the references to what the SEALs can accomplish in less peaceful scenarios. In both these realms, what can be accomplished by men and women of ‘high purpose’ is truly astounding and inspiring. Thanks for highlighting these people.

I joined the Navy back in 1998. At the time, I wanted to be a SEAL. That was my dream and I trained hard for it. The [man made] lake that I lived on was filled with glacier water and I trained myself to swim a mile in it. I found out that SEAL applicants had to swim 50 meters underwater on one breath and by the time I finished high school I could hold my breath for 3 minutes and 15 seconds. I researched everything that I could find and worked out everyday to try and build up my strength, endurance and will power. Unfortunately, when I finally joined the delayed entry program I found out I couldn't even try out as my vision couldn't be any worse than 20/40; mine was 20/400 with severe astigmatism in both eyes. I knew I wanted to do something cool and worthwhile so I ended up settling for the the Navy's nuclear engineering program. But even now, more than 20 years later I still wish I could have been a SEAL; I got such a respect for those guys I can't even describe.

NAVY SEALS ETHOS
In times of war or uncertainty there is a special breed of warrior ready to answer our Nation’s call. Common citizens with uncommon desire to succeed. Forged by adversity, they stand alongside America’s finest special operations forces to serve their country, the American people, and protect their way of life. I am that warrior.

My Trident is a symbol of honor and heritage. Bestowed upon me by the heroes that have gone before, it embodies the trust of those I have sworn to protect. By wearing the Trident I accept the responsibility of my chosen profession and way of life. It is a privilege that I must earn every day.

My loyalty to Country and Team is beyond reproach. I humbly serve as a guardian to my fellow Americans always ready to defend those who are unable to defend themselves. I do not advertise the nature of my work, nor seek recognition for my actions. I voluntarily accept the inherent hazards of my profession, placing the welfare and security of others before my own.

I serve with honor on and off the battlefield. The ability to control my emotions and my actions, regardless of circumstance, sets me apart from others. Uncompromising integrity is my standard. My character and honor are steadfast. My word is my bond.

We expect to lead and be led. In the absence of orders I will take charge, lead my teammates and accomplish the mission. I lead by example in all situations.

I will never quit. I persevere and thrive on adversity. My Nation expects me to be physically harder and mentally stronger than my enemies. If knocked down, I will get back up, every time. I will draw on every remaining ounce of strength to protect my teammates and to accomplish our mission. I am never out of the fight.

We demand discipline. We expect innovation. The lives of my teammates and the success of our mission depend on me - my technical skill, tactical proficiency, and attention to detail. My training is never complete.

We train for war and fight to win. I stand ready to bring the full spectrum of combat power to bear in order to achieve my mission and the goals established by my country. The execution of my duties will be swift and violent when required yet guided by the very principles that I serve to defend.

Brave SEALs have fought and died building the proud tradition and feared reputation that I am bound to uphold. In the worst of conditions, the legacy of my teammates steadies my resolve and silently guides my every deed. I will not fail
